Key Arguments: The legislation violates Australians' right to free speech.
The government is not omniscient and cannot determine absolute truth.
An honest government should not fear what others say.
Free speech is a negative right, meaning it should be free from government interference.
Main Themes: Free speech as a fundamental right
Government overreach and lack of omniscience
Historical and philosophical support for free speech
Notable Quotes: An honest and well-meaning government, like honest and well-meaning people, should have no reason to fear what others say.
The freedom [of speech] is a freedom from governmental action; it is not a right to require others to provide a means of communication.
If there be time to expose through discussion the falsehood and fallacies, to avert the evil by the processes of education, the remedy to be applied is more speech, not enforced silence.
